title: 114_s413
content: The Act titled "Government Settlement Transparency and Reform Act" denies deduction for certain fines, penalties, and other amounts. The Act "Government Settlement Transparency and Reform Act" prohibits deductions for payments to government entities related to law violations or investigations, except for restitution or compliance payments. The taxpayer can deduct any amount established as restitution for damage caused by a law violation or to come into compliance with a violated law. The amount must be identified as restitution or compliance payment in court. The taxpayer can deduct restitution for law violations or compliance payments identified in court orders or settlement agreements. However, reimbursement for investigation or litigation costs is not deductible. The taxpayer can deduct restitution for law violations or compliance payments identified in court orders or settlement agreements. Exceptions include amounts paid for taxes due and amounts paid by reason of any court order in a suit where no government entity is involved. Certain nongovernmental regulatory entities may be treated as governmental entities for tax purposes. The amendment allows nongovernmental entities with self-regulatory powers to be treated as governmental entities for tax purposes. It applies to amounts paid or incurred after the enactment date, except for pre-existing binding orders or agreements. SEC. 6050X. INFORMATION WITH RESPECT TO CERTAIN FINES, PENALTIES, AND OTHER AMOUNTS. Requirement of Reporting: The appropriate official of any government or entity involved in a suit or agreement must report the amount to be paid, including restitution, remediation, and compliance with violated laws. The paragraph describes a suit or agreement related to a violation of laws where the government or entity has authority, including court orders or agreements made during investigations or inquiries. The government or entity conducts an inquiry into potential law violations, with an aggregate amount of $600 or more in court orders and agreements. The Secretary can adjust the reporting threshold as needed for efficient administration of internal revenue laws. The required return must be filed when the agreement is entered into, as determined by the Secretary. Every person making a return under subsection (a) must provide a written statement to each party involved in the settlement, including the name of the government or entity and the information submitted to the Secretary. The statement should be given at the same time the government or entity submits the required information to the Secretary. The term 'appropriate official' refers to the individual in charge of the suit, investigation, or inquiry. The table of sections for subpart B of part III of subchapter A of chapter 61 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by inserting a new item after section 6050W. The amendments made by this section apply to fines, penalties, and other amounts paid or incurred on or after the enactment date of the Act, except for amounts under binding orders or agreements entered into before that date. This exception does not apply to orders or agreements requiring court approval unless approval was obtained before the enactment date.
